Module org.microbean.type
Package org.microbean.type

Class Type<T>

java.lang.Object
org.microbean.type.Type<T>
Type Parameters:
T - the type of the thing representing a Java type that is being adapted; often a java.lang.reflect.Type or some other framework's representation of one
All Implemented Interfaces:
Owner<T>
Direct Known Subclasses:
JavaType
@Experimental public abstract class Type<T> extends Object implements Owner<T>
A value-like object representing a (Java-like) type for purposes of testing assignability.

Concisely: Types represent java.lang.reflect.Types (or other frameworks' similar representations) without any dependence on java.lang.reflect.Type itself.

This class is used directly primarily by the Type.Semantics class and its subclasses.

Author:
Laird Nelson
See Also:
  • Type.Semantics

    Type.CdiSemantics
    A Type.VariantSemantics implementation that implements the rules of typesafe resolution.
    static class 
    Type.CovariantSemantics
    A Type.VariantSemantics implementation that implements Java type assignability semantics, which are covariant.
    static class 
    Type.InvariantSemantics
    A Type.VariantSemantics implementation that does not permit subtyping, but that compares wildcard types covariantly.
    static class 
    Type.Semantics
    An abstract embodiment of Type assignability rules.
    static class 
    Type.VariantSemantics
    An abstract partial Type.Semantics that permits subtyping.

    • Type

      protected Type(List<? extends Type<T>> supertypes)
      Creates a new Type that models custom supertypes.

      Among other things, this means that the object() method will return null.

      Parameters:
      supertypes - the custom supertypes; must not be null
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if supertypes is null

      @OverridingEncouraged public boolean named()
      Returns true if and only if this Type represents a Java type that has a name.

      In the Java reflective type system, only Class and TypeVariable instances have names.

    • top

      public abstract boolean top()
      Returns true if and only if this Type represents the uppermost reference type in the type system.

      In all practical cases, if an implementation of this method returns true, it means this Type represents Object.class.

      Undefined behavior will result if an implementation does not meet these requirements.

      Returns:
      true if and only if this Type represents the uppermost reference type in the type system, e.g. Object.class
      Idempotency:
      Implementations of this method must be idempotent and deterministic.
      Thread Safety:
      Implementations of this method must be safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • directSupertypes

      public final List<? extends Type<T>> directSupertypes()
      Returns a (possibly cached) List of this Type's direct supertypes, defined to be its immediate superclass or supertype, if any, and any interfaces it directly implements.
      Returns:
      a (possibly cached) List of this Type's direct supertypes
      See Also:
      • computeDirectSupertypes()
      Idempotency:
      This method is idempotent and deterministic.
      Nullability:
      This method never returns null.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • computeDirectSupertypes

      protected List<? extends Type<T>> computeDirectSupertypes()
      Returns an unmodifiable and immutable List of the direct supertypes of this Type, or an empty List if there are no direct supertypes, or if this Type implementation does not distinguish between direct and non-direct supertypes.

      The direct supertypes of a type are defined to be those analogous to those described by the Java Language Specification, section 4.10.2, minus any types featuring wildcards.

      The List returned must not contain this and must have no null or duplicate elements.

      The ordering within the returned List is not specified, but must be deterministic between invocations.

      The size of the List returned must not change between calls.

      Undefined behavior will result if an implementation does not meet these requirements.

      The default implementation of this method returns an empty List. Many subclasses may wish to override this behavior.

      Returns:
      an unmodifiable and immutable List of the direct supertypes of this Type; never null
      See Also:
      • JavaTypes.directSupertypes(java.lang.reflect.Type)
      • directSupertypes()
      • supertypes()
      • computeSupertypes()
      Idempotency:
      This method is, and its overrides must be, idempotent and deterministic.
      Nullability:
      This method does not, and its overrides must not, return null.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is, and its overrides must be, safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • type

      public abstract Type<T> type()
      If this Type represents a parameterized type or a generic array type, returns a Type representing its raw type or generic component type, or, if this Type does not represent a parameterized type or a generic array type, returns this.

      Undefined behavior will result if an implementation does not meet these requirements.

      Specified by:
      type in interface Owner<T>
      Returns:
      a suitable Type; never null; often this
      Idempotency:
      Overrides of this method must be idempotent and deterministic.
      Nullability:
      Overrides of this method must not return null.
      Thread Safety:
      Overrides of this method must be safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • componentType

      public abstract Type<T> componentType()
      Returns the component type of this Type, if there is one, or null if there is not.

      Overrides of this method must return a non-null result only when this Type represents a type that is either an array or a generic array type.

      Undefined behavior will result if an implementation does not meet these requirements.

      Returns:
      the component type of this Type, if there is one, or null if there is not

    • lowerBounds

      public abstract List<? extends Type<T>> lowerBounds()
      Returns an unmodifiable List of this Type's lower bounds.

      The returned List will be non-empty if and only if this Type models a lower-bounded wildcard type.

      Undefined behavior will result if an implementation does not meet these requirements.

      Returns:
      an unmodifiable List of this Type's lower bounds; never null; often empty
      Idempotency:
      Overrides of this method must be idempotent and deterministic.

      Overrides of this method must not return null.
      Thread Safety:
      Overrides of this method must be safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • upperBounds

      public abstract List<? extends Type<T>> upperBounds()
      Returns an unmodifiable List of this Type's upper bounds.

      The returned List will be non-empty if and only if this Type models either a type variable, an unbounded wildcard type, or an upper-bounded wildcard type.

      Undefined behavior will result if an implementation does not meet these requirements.

      Returns:
      an unmodifiable List of this Type's upper bounds; never null; often empty
      Idempotency:
      Overrides of this method must be idempotent and deterministic.
      Nullability:
      Overrides of this method must not return null.
      Thread Safety:
      Overrides of this method must be safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • customSupertyped

      public final boolean customSupertyped()
      Returns true if and only if this Type models a custom list of supertypes and nothing else.

      This method returns true when and only when all of the following conditions are met:

      • The object() method returns null
      • The hasTypeArguments() method returns false
      • The arrayType() method returns false
      • The lowerBounded() method returns false
      • The upperBounded() method returns false
      • The named() method returns false
      Returns:
      true if and only if this type models a custom list of supertypes and nothing else
      See Also:
      • supertypes()
      • Type(List)
      Idempotency:
      This method is idempotent and deterministic.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

      public final boolean classOrInterface()
      Returns true if and only if this Type models a class or interface.

      This method returns true if and only if named() returns true and upperBounded() returns false.

    • supertypes

      public final List<? extends Type<T>> supertypes()
      Returns all the supertypes of this Type (which normally includes this Type).

      This method returns a cached list of supertypes, or, if such a list does not yet exist, returns the result of invoking the computeSupertypes() method.

      Returns:
      an unmodifiable List containing all the supertypes of this Type (which normally includes this Type); never null; never empty
      See Also:
      • computeSupertypes()
      Idempotency:
      This method is idempotent and deterministic.
      Nullability:
      This method does not return null.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • computeSupertypes

      protected List<? extends Type<T>> computeSupertypes()
      Returns all the supertypes of this Type (which normally includes this Type).

      The returned List must not be null and must not be empty. Undefined behavior will result if overrides do not adhere to this requirement.

      The order of elements within the List returned by any invocation of this method must be deterministic. Undefined behavior will result if overrides do not adhere to this requirement.

      The default implementation of this method reflexively and transitively applies the direct supertype relation (represented by the directSupertypes() method) to this Type and returns an unmodifiable List containing the result.

      Returns:
      an unmodifiable Collection containing all the supertypes of this Type (which includes this Type); never null; never empty
      See Also:
      • supertypes()
      • directSupertypes()
      • computeDirectSupertypes()
      Idempotency:
      This method is, and its overrides must be, idempotent and deterministic.
      Nullability:
      This method does not, and its overrides must not, return null.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is, and its overrides must be, safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • supertypeOf

      @Convenience public final boolean supertypeOf(Type<?> sub)
      Returns true if and only if this Type is a supertype of the supplied Type.

      This method uses a combination of the supertypes() method and the equals(Type, Type) method in its implementation.

      Parameters:
      sub - the purported subtype; must not be null
      Returns:
      true if and only if this Type is a supertype of the supplied Type
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if sub is null
      See Also:
      • supertypes()
      • equals(Type, Type)
      Idempotency:
      This method is idempotent and deterministic.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • subtypeOf

      @Convenience public final boolean subtypeOf(Type<?> sup)
      Returns true if and only if this Type is a subtype of the supplied Type.

      This method uses a combination of the supertypes() method and the equals(Type, Type) method in its implementation.

      Parameters:
      sup - the purported supertype; must not be null
      Returns:
      true if and only if this Type is a subtype of the supplied Type
      Throws:
      NullPointerException - if sup is null
      See Also:
      • supertypes()
      • equals(Type, Type)
      Idempotency:
      This method is idempotent and deterministic.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • mostSpecialized

      public final Type<T> mostSpecialized(Predicate<? super Type<T>> p)
      Returns a Type, selected from this Type's supertypes, that is the most specialized of those supertypes and that passes the test represented by the supplied Predicate.

      Often this method will return this Type itself, since normally the set of supertypes of a type include the type itself.

      Parameters:
      p - the Predicate imposing additional restructions; must not be null
      Returns:
      the most specialized Type meeting the conditions above; often this Type itself
      See Also:
      • supertypes()
      • customSupertyped()
      Idempotency:
      This method is idempotent and deterministic provided that the supplied Predicate is deterministic.
      Nullability:
      This method may return null.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • hashCode

      public int hashCode()
      Overrides:
      hashCode in class Object

    • equals

      public boolean equals(Object other)
      Overrides:
      equals in class Object

    • hashCode

      public static final int hashCode(Type<?> type)
      Returns a hashcode for the supplied Type, independent of its particular implementation of the Object.hashCode() method.
      Parameters:
      type - the Type; may be null
      Returns:
      a hashcode for the supplied Type
      See Also:
      • equals(Type, Type)
      Idempotency:
      This method is idempotent and deterministic.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.

    • equals

      public static final boolean equals(Type<?> t1, Type<?> t2)
      Returns true if and only if the two supplied Types are equal, based solely upon the properties publicly exposed by the Type class.
      Parameters:
      t1 - the first Type; may be null
      t2 - the second Type; may be null
      Returns:
      true if and only if the two supplied Types are equal, based solely upon the properties publicly exposed by the Type abstract class
      See Also:
      • hashCode(Type)
      Idempotency:
      This method is idempotent and deterministic.
      Thread Safety:
      This method is safe for concurrent use by multiple threads.
